asset.taxonomy: opinion/France’s War Within (17kauffmann)
asset.assetTitle: France’s War Within (17kauffmann)

newswire.title: France’s War Within

multimedia.caption: Paris on Monday.
Paris on Monday.
Paris on Monday.
Paris on Monday.

org_facet: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
newswire.abstract: An embattled republic fights abroad, but also faces threats at home.

comments.commentBody:
Readers of this column must read Prof. Krugman's column yesterday in these very pages of the NYT. Here is the link, in case you did not:

http://www.nytimes.com/2015/11/16/opinion/fearing-fear-itself.html

In it he notes that "the biggest danger terrorism poses to our society comes not from the direct harm inflicted, but from the wrong-headed responses it can inspire."
There is a danger in labeling this a war or calling it an existential threat. It is neither. Using these terms and language is facile because it will allow the French government to invoke certain laws and engage in certain actions, but beyond that it is more dysfunctional than useful.
So, even as we face and counter these atrocities, as we must, let us not fall into the trap of labeling it as war and escalating the situation. In the aftermath of the attacks on the WTC W and his coterie used it as an opportunity to "spread freedom and democracy" with disastrous results. So, pause, take a deep breath, and call it what it is - an unprovoked terrorist attack.

newswire.title: Finding Peace Within the Holy Texts
org_facet: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
newswire.abstract: The answer to ending religious violence will probably be found within religion itself.

comments.commentBody:
Brooks notes, "The secular substitutes for religion — nationalism, racism and political ideology — have all led to disaster. So many flock to religion, sometimes — especially within Islam — to extremist forms."
This is a false premise that then allows him to build a superstructure, but like anything built on shaky foundations, the superstructure will rumble and collapse.
The REAL secular substitute for religion is science and the scientific method. And that has brought us much good, although some of that good has also been appropriated for evil as well.
At the very least I expect Brooks to state a defensible and correct premise and not engage in sloppy and indefensible comparisons.

newswire.title: Austerity’s Grim Legacy
newswire.abstract: The deficit fetishism that led to government cutbacks has been more destructive in the long run than even its critics anticipated.

comments.commentBody: A government's mandate is to care for all citizens, not just the top 10% or 1% or an even thinner upper crust. And the one way it can carry out this mandate is to spend, particularly on social programs and infrastructure, money when the private sector is not doing its fair share. This is ECON101. Austerity, on the other hand, is akin to starving the poor to feed the rich. And anyone recommending austerity in times of economic slowdown must be booted out of office.

newswire.abstract: A Pew survey captures how working parents are feeling shorted on time with their children, friends, partners or hobbies.

comments.commentBody:
"She said policies like paid family leave and after-school child care would significantly ease parents’ stress. Yet today, families mostly figure out the juggle on their own."

This is a sign of a society that is oblivious to the social needs of its citizens. Most modern advanced societies provide support for its citizens through policies that include pre-K child care, paid paternal vacation, more liberal sick days, etc. We in America are left to figure out solutions on our own. Basically government has abandoned its fundamental duty to its citizens.

Moreover, all we hear are snarky remarks from the likes of Jeb Bush who spoke disparagingly of the "French work week" while admonishing Marco Rubio. And we have to suffer through the irony displayed in Paul Ryan's unwillingness to compromise on his own family time but offering no support for that in his budget.

It is high time to throw out of office those who do not support social programs that benefit Americans across the board. It is high time America joins other advanced societies and enters the 21st century.

Enough said.

asset.assetTitle: Gotcha, G.O.P. (02blow)

newswire.title: Gotcha, G.O.P.
newswire.abstract: The Republican candidates, especially Ben Carson, appear to want to say little and avoid tough questions.

comments.commentBody:
"Gotcha questions have come to mean any question one doesn’t want to answer, any question whose answer would or could reveal something unflattering."
Yes, gotcha questions are defined to be thus by the wannabe candidates. And, yes, some of them are gotcha questions and some are not. But what bothers me is this: Will the wannabe candidate, once s/he becomes the POTUS, tell the global media that s/he whine about being asked a gotcha question by the German or Russian or French reporters?
The wannabe POTUS will have to get used to living in the glare of the spotlight and be used to answering uncomfortable questions. Let us, the public, decide if it was a gotcha question or not.

asset.taxonomy: opinion/Church, State, and the Supreme Court’s Moment of Truth (29greenhouse)
asset.assetTitle: Church, State, and the Supreme Court’s Moment of Truth (29greenhouse)

taxonomies.name: Church, State, and the Supreme Court’s Moment of Truth (29greenhouse)

newswire.title: Church, State, and the Supreme Court’s Moment of Truth
newswire.abstract: For some religious nonprofits, the Hobby Lobby decision doesn’t go far enough.

comments.commentBody:
In a section about people's beliefs as to when life begins or what is contraception Ms. Greenhouse notes "Their belief doesn’t happen to be scientifically correct."

So I can believe anything; it does not have to be correct for me to oppose or support a policy. If I believe that Mexicans are rapists (as some famous voices have noted) then can I be excused from hiring Mexicans in my business? Or not serve Mexicans in my restaurant? Or begin the program of deporting them en mass? After all, my belief need not be correct or valid.

Later she notes that "Beliefs are relevant in a public policy context only when they are invoked to impinge on the rights of others." In other words, my beliefs - correct or incorrect, valid or invalid - has to impinge on "the rights of others." As far as I can tell providing a comprehensive healthcare that includes contraception does not negative;y impinge on "the rights of others." If anything, it facilitates "the rights of others."

SO, what is the basis, other than pure politics, for any judge to support plaintiffs?

The Senate Democrats (rightly) demanded that the RNC pay the committee's bill since it was not a Congressional hearing but a Republican party political witch hunt.
However, the reality is that Hillary Clinton has benefited a great deal and so the RNC may (wrongly) argue that she has to pay for the "free" advertising she received!

Maybe we can coin a new term "Gowdy," as in Hillary got a Gowdy, an effect in which the opponent you wish to hurt actually benefits from your actions.

We're giving love in a family dose

asset.taxonomy: opinion/Crimes Without Punishment? (21edsall)
asset.assetTitle: Crimes Without Punishment? (21edsall)

newswire.title: Crimes Without Punishment?
newswire.abstract: The liberal Capitol Hill neighborhood in Washington, D.C. provides a test case in the national debate over high incarceration rates.

comments.commentBody:
Thomas Edsall notes "That may be what’s happening on the national level but locally, it gets complicated, especially in more liberal neighborhoods." The "That" in "That may be what’s happening on the national level " he means that those advocating leniency seem to have gained the upper hand and that there is a growing bipartisan agreement on that as well. But, as he also notes, "it gets complicated, especially in more liberal neighborhoods."

In other words, even though there may be some agreement at the national level there is not much agreement at the local level. Fundamentally this is because the view from 30,000 feet up in the sky - which is where policies get framed - is very different from the ground view - which is where most people live every day. This discordance between the national and local perspectives is also driven by NIMBY attitudes. Those framing lenient policies tend to live in less crime ridden neighborhoods, if not, in exclusive gated communities and have no personal experience of the street level crimes. They don't see it in their "backyards" and hence assume that nobody sees it in their backyards. Those who live in crime ridden neighborhoods actually experience it very closely and hence call for more stringent punishment.

I have no idea how these two discordant views can be reconciled.

asset.taxonomy: opinion/Are You Sure You Want the Job? (21friedman)
asset.assetTitle: Are You Sure You Want the Job? (21friedman)

taxonomies.name: Are You Sure You Want the Job? (21friedman)

newswire.title: Are You Sure You Want the Job?
org_facet: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
newswire.abstract: Battles between superpowers and superempowered angry men and teams of cybercriminals and cyberterrorists await our next president.

comments.commentBody:
Mr. Friedman notes that "When you are advancing, you buy the system; you don’t care who’s a billionaire, because your life is improving. But when you stop advancing, added Dobbs, you can “lose faith in the system."

This is not all that new notion. When the economy is expanding and "all boats are rising" nobody cares who is on the top rung because the economy is not perceived as a zero-sum game. Instead it is seen as one in which al parties can win. But when the ladder of opportunity and growth is being pulled from under one's feet and the economy becomes a zero-sum game - you win, therefore I lose - then we begin to look at the guy on the top rung of the ladder with disdain and anger.

The anger that results from lack of opportunities in a system that seems rigged for the rich and against the average man can be dangerous and lead to seismic changes. If only the top 1% is smart enough to recognize this and willingly agree to pay a higher share of their income as taxes that can be used to advance everyone's interest, this anger can be blunted.

The top tier cannot be eating cake while denying bread to the remaining 99%. That is a dangerous recipe fraught with explosive potential.

asset.taxonomy: upshot/Bernie Sanders, Democratic Socialist Capitalist (20up-socialist)
asset.assetTitle: Bernie Sanders, Democratic Socialist Capitalist (20up-socialist)

newswire.title: Bernie Sanders, Democratic Socialist Capitalist

multimedia.caption: Bernie Sanders and Hillary Rodham Clinton at last week's Democratic debate.
Bernie Sanders and Hillary Rodham Clinton at last week's Democratic debate.
Bernie Sanders and Hillary Rodham Clinton at last week's Democratic debate.
Bernie Sanders and Hillary Rodham Clinton at last week's Democratic debate.

newswire.abstract: The senator from Vermont calls himself a socialist, but he doesn’t want to nationalize the steel mills. Or anything else, actually.

comments.commentBody:
Sadly most Americans do not fully understand the term "socialism" or what it means to be called a "socialist." They have a knee jerk negative reaction. But the truth is that America (yes, I mean the one that is considered to be exceptional) has a substantial portion of its economy in the public sector. We are all fortunate to have social security, unemployment insurance, SNAP, and other programs that provide a safety net.

Does that mean we have a socialist economy? No. It only means that we have programs that are common to many modern economies that believe in providing maximum security to its citizens.

Bernie Sanders is exactly what he says he is - a believer in a free market economy, one in which the law of the jungle (might is right) is reined in with common sense and decency.

asset.taxonomy: opinion/Osama Bin Laden’s First Draft (20nocera)
asset.assetTitle: Osama Bin Laden’s First Draft (20nocera)

newswire.title: Osama Bin Laden’s First Draft
newswire.abstract: Jonathan Mahler’s piece on the Osama bin Laden raid is as much about the nature of journalism as it is about the facts surrounding the event.

comments.commentBody:
I too found the Mahler article balanced. He did not buy into the conspiracy theories but only suggested that, with the passage of time, new information may come up that may require us to modify the current narrative.

History is often mistaken to be a recording of "facts" and therefore people believe it to be the "truth." In reality, though, recorded history depends on who the scribe is. By noting this I am not necessarily claiming that historians lie or twist facts (although that too happens) but simply that it is a narrative from one vantage point.

For those who don;t fully buy into this notion I urge you to see Roshomon!

newswire.abstract: It's good that people are more demanding, but the epidemic of food intolerance has gone way over the top.

comments.commentBody: Cohen concludes that "the epidemic of food intolerance has gone way over the top" and that may very well be true even if a bit harsh. But leaving aside the "food fad" which should more realistically be called "food intolerance" the more important point is that "much of humanity still does not" have their basic food needs met. Global food security should be the watchword, not gluten free.

asset.taxonomy: opinion/An Admissions Surprise From the Ivy League (18bruni)
asset.assetTitle: An Admissions Surprise From the Ivy League (18bruni)

taxonomies.name: An Admissions Surprise From the Ivy League (18bruni)

newswire.title: An Admissions Surprise From the Ivy League
org_facet: Coalition for Access, Affordability and Success
newswire.abstract: Exclusive schools say they want more diversity. Will a new application process really get them there?

comments.commentBody:
This is yet another example of a well intended program whose mechanics and optics are off base.
To help under privileged kids in high school the solution is to create a new web platform and ask them to begin filing away information from 9th grade onward so that the student can build a portfolio. Kids with lower access to and experience with technology are being asked to use this new platform. Can you spot the problem?
And this does not even address the question of unintended consequences. As Bruni notes, affluent parents will "turn the entire high school experience into a calculated, pragmatic audition for college admissions officers." The mad scramble for a "better and great looking" college application will now begin in the 9th grade. All I can say is WOW. what were they thinkin

asset.assetTitle: Guess Who Else Is a Socialist? (16egan)

taxonomies.name: Guess Who Else Is a Socialist? (16egan)

newswire.title: Guess Who Else Is a Socialist?
newswire.abstract: We don’t like ‘them.’ But we do like many of their ideas. At its best the system can run an army, and health care, and provide quality education.

comments.commentBody:
Most Americans do not like "casino capitalism" and yet are afraid of embracing "socialism" because they do not fully understand it or realize that big parts of the current American economy is indeed in the public sector.
It is this ignorance that is exploited by these politicians. And, no pundit has taken or will take the responsibility to explain to the lay public what it means.
Thus we are where we are, common people fearing socialism and politicians exploiting that fear. Thanks to Bernie Sanders we may finally see some shift in knowledge and attitudes. We should be thankful to him, at the very least, for that.

newswire.abstract: With a poised, polished performance, she eclipsed Bernie Sanders in their first face-off of the race.

comments.commentBody:
I can only hope that at least some of those millions who tuned in to watch the Republican debate tuned in to watch the Democratic debate yesterday. I can only hope that they saw the substantial difference between the two debates. And I can only hope that they get a little more scared of supporting one from that Republican pool.
But, even as I hope for all of the above, I am not holding my breath. After all we are still debating gun control after a massive string of mass shootings. Why should I expect the extreme fringe elements to change their extreme fringe views?

Daniel Webster is a perfect example of the extremists who work in the government and rather than trying to make it more functional and helpful propose to completely dismantle it. asset.assetTitle: It’s All Benghazi (09krugman)

newswire.title: It’s All Benghazi
newswire.abstract: The House hearings intended to hurt Hillary Clinton are just one case of politicians capitalizing on a nonissue. Remember the debt crisis?

comments.commentBody: Thanks for calling out the pundits Prof. Krugman. I have never understood why pundits attempt to always frame every debate in the form of "One the one hand, but on the other hand" manner when there is only one obviously right answer. Is it because they wish to appear fair minded? But then, there is nothing fair minded in elevating stupid arguments. Pundits should do what they are supposed to do - inform and educate the people of this country, not anoint stupid and illogical arguments as credible alternatives.

asset.taxonomy: opinion/Hillary Clinton’s Opportunist Solution! (09brooks)
asset.assetTitle: Hillary Clinton’s Opportunist Solution! (09brooks)

newswire.title: Hillary Clinton’s Opportunist Solution!
newswire.abstract: Hillary Clinton no longer even pretends to be consistent or authentic, but maybe that can work with voters and in office.

comments.commentBody:
If Mr. Brooks spent one half of the time he spends on analyzing Hillary Clinton's flip flops on the blatant lies mouthed by his team of GOP aspirants, he'll find material to write an entire thesis instead of just one column.

But the most egregious statement in this column is his labeling Ben Carson alongside Bernie Sanders as "conviction politician." Ben Carson has no convictions of his own and the few that he has - he will not support a Muslim for the office of POTUS, for instance - are dangerous and extreme.

So, please spend less time in counting Hillary Clinton's flip flops and spend more time in derailing the clown caravan of feckless GOP aspirants.

"It has been correctly observed that her ascent in the polls, coupled with Donald Trump’s enduringly strong showing, reflects the currency of political outsiders right now."
All the pundits keep on repeating this theory, according to which it is the outsider status that is propelling Fiorina, Trump and Carson.
A much simpler and more obvious explanation is that a large swath of Americans believe and buy into the nonsense doled out by these "outsiders." And that is the scary part of this story.

asset.taxonomy: opinion/The Big University (06brooks)
asset.assetTitle: The Big University (06brooks)

newswire.title: The Big University
newswire.abstract: Many universities founded as religious institutions have needlessly dropped a key original goal: educating students’ emotional, spiritual and moral sides.

comments.commentBody:
Mr. Brooks, as his is wont, opens with an axiomatic statement that "Many American universities were founded as religious institutions, explicitly designed to cultivate their students’ spiritual and moral natures."
It is rather simplistic and convenient because he can then follow up by referring to the changes in these institutions. He seems to forget that many more American universities were founded as agricultural colleges. But with the changing times and technological developments, these institutions shifted their focus from just agriculture to other topics that were more current and germane.
Likewise he simply avers that we inherited the Greek, Jewish and Christian traditions and, in the process, overlooks many other rich traditions that include Chinese, Hindu and Buddhist aspects. Here too, he limits his references merely to advance his arguments.
It would be an anachronism to teach kids how to till the soil with a horse and plow these days.

newswire.title: Jeb Bush: Crying Out Loud
newswire.abstract: Most of his speeches ooze over me like cold gruel. But there’s one special phrase, when I hear it, that tells me to perk up and pay attention.

comments.commentBody:
Jeb! made Terry Schaivo a household name by politicizing what should have been a personal family decision. Ask Terry's husband, for crying out loud.

Jeb! with the help of Katherine Harris blocked the counting of votes in Florida and helped his brother get into the White House. Ask the American people how that went, for crying out loud.

Jeb! takes credit for an economic boom when he was Governor but not for the bust that followed the housing bubble, which was the primary reason for the preceding boom. Ask homeowners in Florida who were left with debts larger than the value of their house, for crying out loud.

comments.commentBody:
That the video depicting the alleged sale of body parts was, as Gail Collins aptly put "false, false, false" but Representative John Duncan Jr., a Tennessee Republican would not believe it. Like his other GOP colleagues, he lives in a make believe world where humans have no impact on climate, a woman's body would block an unwanted pregnancy in case of a "legitimate rape," and unless we expel all Muslims from the USA Shariah law will become the law of this land.

It is simultaneously sad, funny, and scary. Sad, because of the state of governance in our country. Funny, because it provides comedians an endless supply of jokes that the provides me some cathartic relief. Scary, because such people not only exist but manage to get elected.

newswire.abstract: Forget Tip O’Neill, political scientists say. Republicans can count on three key trends to counter the idea that demographics determine electoral destiny.

comments.commentBody:
There was no mention of voting districts that are created to support one party or the other. In this regard, both parties are about as guilty as each other. However, the beneficiaries have been Republicans. Even after winning more votes (50.7% to 49.3%), arguably a slight margin, Democrats won only 46.2% of seats, a far greater loss than the small margin would have led us to expect.

This is made possible entirely because of gerrymandering voting districts. It is high time to have an amendment that makes nonpartisan commissions responsible for creating voting districts.

asset.assetTitle: The Prison Problem (29brooks)

newswire.title: The Prison Problem
newswire.abstract: The war on drugs and sentencing laws are often blamed for packed cells, but that explanation’s wrong, and the true causes are even harder to reverse.

comments.commentBody: An important driver, maybe the most important one, missing in this analysis - employment opportunities. I suspect that if we were able to strengthen our economy, by re-building our crumbling infrastructure as one example, we should be able to blunt this problem. But that requires a Congress to open its purse strings, something they are willing to do only for the rich and not for those in prison.

comments.commentBody:
If Congressional districts were to be carved by a nonpartisan group and not by the Congress(wo)men themselves, I believe there would be very few GOP members elected to Congress. They get elected because they have created districts that make them and their positions electable. As evidence, in the last election, Democrats got more votes but fewer seats.
It is time to take away the job of carving districts from these folks and hand it to nonpartisan groups.

Speaker Boehner sat atop the angry group that became the Tea Party; a group that he helped create. And now the group has turned their backs on him and are willing to sacrifice him on the altar of ideological purity.

Old jungle saying: The hand that feeds the snake must also worry about being bitten.

newswire.title: The American Idea and Today’s G.O.P.
newswire.abstract: American exceptionalism is built on immigration, not threatened by it, as most Republicans believe.

comments.commentBody:
"Instead the pessimism grows from a sour, overgeneralized and intellectually sloppy sense of alienation."

Yes, there is a fear and malaise gripping the country. And there is a good dose of intellectual sloppiness accompanying it. GWB did not like did not like or promote nuanced analysis. "Mission Accomplished" was a simple, sloppy and false image that he advertised. Obama brought a dose of deeper and richer understanding, but was crowded out by the Great Opposition Party. In this milieu arose Faux News that constantly fed Americans a diet of America's exceptionalism.

The intellectual sloppiness did happen overnight; it was planted, watered and nurtured by Faux News and others in the media including Mr. Brooks himself. It will take decades to undo the psychological damage done the country.

newswire.title: A Pope for All Species
newswire.abstract: Francis’ empathy lifts humans, animals and Christianity itself.

comments.commentBody:
"Indeed, here’s the delicious irony: Pope Francis is revered even by many atheists."
This is ironic at the superficial level only, in the sense that the unbelievers are believing in the leader of the believers.
However, it is far from ironic, and actually makes a lot of sense, if you do not view the Pope as a leader of believers but as a leader of the humanity, compassion, accommodation, sharing, and the like. And it is for that reason that atheists are in love with this Pope.

newswire.abstract: Cooperation between America and Middle East nations would be more effective in ensuring compliance than simply stepping up threats against Tehran.

comments.commentBody:
Israel is the top aid recipient from the United States having received over $25 billion in military aid from the United States and has a stockpile of over 200 nuclear warheads.
And all we get in return is more carping from Bibi who wants to interfere and topple this administration. Any country that tried to interfere with America's internal affairs would have been told firmly to back off, and yet all we hear from Israel is how shabbily they have been treated by the United States.
I think we have many better things to do, like building our crumbling bridges and roads and supporting school teachers, with the $25 billion.

comments.commentBody:
"One serious consequence of this oversensitivity to criticism is that narcissistic leaders often do not listen when they feel threatened or attacked."

Do the names of some very very infamous leaders who did not heed any counsel come to your mind? I can name quite a few beginning from the Roman times all the way until the second world war. They all eventually went down in flames but not before dragging their fellow countrymen along with them.

So beware of what you wish for in a leader.

newswire.title: Scott Walker’s Cocktail of Ignorance
newswire.abstract: Too many Republican candidates are too cavalier about the knowledge and preparation that a president should have.

comments.commentBody:
This cocktail of ignorance has driven me to drinking any cocktail within reach.

As for etiquette prevailing, I wonder where that was when a man in New Hampshire referred to our POTUS as a Muslim and The Donald praised him for asking an important question. Later when asked why he did not correct the man, The Donald said that he did not want to violate his first amendment right to free speech.

Since when has yelling "FIRE" in a crowded theater been protected by the first amendment, I wonder. Bring on the whiskey and soda, or better yet give it to me straight.

asset.taxonomy: opinion/Pope Francis, the Prince of the Personal (22brooks)
asset.assetTitle: Pope Francis, the Prince of the Personal (22brooks)

taxonomies.name: Pope Francis, the Prince of the Personal (22brooks)

newswire.title: Pope Francis, the Prince of the Personal
newswire.abstract: On Francis’ visit, he will offer a model on listening and learning, and upholding moral standards while remaining loving and merciful.

comments.commentBody:
"Francis has consistently criticized abstract intellectual systems that speak in crude generalities, instrumentalize the poor and ignore the rich idiosyncratic nature of each soul and situation."

After reading this line I feel compelled to drag in the "abstract intellectual" analysis that David himself provides from time to time. As for our political class, there aren't many who has experiennced poverty or unemployment to have been able to learn "through intimacy" and hence end up labeling them as "welfare queens" (St. Reagan) or the "takers" (Mr. Mittens).

I am not suggesting that every one must have a personal experience to see the "granular details" but at the very least I expect that it "arouses a sense of respect" for the under-privileged in the privileged class. Instead those fortunate enough to have escaped the harsh reality of poverty and unemployment revile those who have the misfortune not to have escaped. And that is unconscionable.

newswire.title: The (Fake) Meat Revolution

multimedia.copyright: Bill & Brigitte Clough/AgStock Images, via Corbis
multimedia.caption: Scientists think they’re getting closer to the day you won’t be able to tell whether your steak started out growing out of the ground or grazing on it.

multimedia.copyright: Bill & Brigitte Clough/AgStock Images, via Corbis
multimedia.caption: Scientists think they’re getting closer to the day you won’t be able to tell whether your steak started out growing out of the ground or grazing on it.

multimedia.copyright: Bill & Brigitte Clough/AgStock Images, via Corbis
multimedia.caption: Scientists think they’re getting closer to the day you won’t be able to tell whether your steak started out growing out of the ground or grazing on it.

multimedia.copyright: Bill & Brigitte Clough/AgStock Images, via Corbis
multimedia.caption: Scientists think they’re getting closer to the day you won’t be able to tell whether your steak started out growing out of the ground or grazing on it.

newswire.abstract: Researchers are getting closer to providing us with cheap alternatives to meat that even carnivores will enjoy.

comments.commentBody:
"Moreover, prices are still a bit higher than real meat."
The problem with this trend towards "faux" meat products is that they too require a lot of processing, which is part of the reason why prices are (and will always be) higher.
Why not simply eat the veggies, legumes, lentils, fava beans, quinoa, or any other plant-based product directly? What adds taste to any product are the vast range of spices. Combine spices in different proportions and you get an infinite range of options to make food tasty and appealing.
We do not have to rely on scientists to manufacture tastes for us when we can be our own scientists (or cooks, if you prefer an ancient outdated term) in our kitchens.

newswire.abstract: The Grand Old Party is changing, but not to the extreme it’s flirted with this summer.

comments.commentBody:
"So far, Fiorina has looked like the most impressive candidate."
She who will bomb anyone or anything within here reach is impressing Mr. Brooks. I wonder if deep down he is still in favor of beating the war drums, as he was doing in the past.

"Rubio is young and thus uncorrupted."
He who has deeply borrowed and is indebted to a car dealer is uncorrupted. He who mixes up his personal and candidate accounts is uncorrupted. It is time for Mr. Brooks to look up the meaning of that word.

Seriously, please look up the meaning of no bombs, no corruption in the dictionary. That's where you'll find Bernie Sanders. Are you feeling the Bern??

Why would not Iranians think America is either deceitful or duplicitous?

newswire.abstract: The state plans to put Richard Glossip to death in the face of mounting evidence that he is innocent.

comments.commentBody:
Governor Wolf of Pennsylvania voice most people's concerns about the " “the accuracy and fundamental fairness” of judgments in case of capital punishment. There is abundant evidence that many on death row are innocent but were improperly charged. There is also the fundamental paradox and moral unfairness of punishing a murderer by taking his life.

But what else can we expect from Oklahoma, a state that assigned personhood to an unborn fetus. Thankfully the state Supreme Court struck down that law as unconstitutional.

We can only surmise that an unborn fetus is more important than taking away an innocent man's life in Oklahoma. I wonder when Oklahoma plans to welcome the 20th century and join the rest of the union and civilized world.

asset.taxonomy: opinion/Walls, Borders, a Dome and Refugees (09friedman)
asset.assetTitle: Walls, Borders, a Dome and Refugees (09friedman)

taxonomies.name: Walls, Borders, a Dome and Refugees (09friedman)

des_facet: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
newswire.title: Walls, Borders, a Dome and Refugees
newswire.abstract: The fallout of collapsing countries continues to spill into our orderly world, and just isolating ourselves won’t change that.

comments.commentBody:
The three Ms, i.e., Mother Nature, Moore's law, and Market, are all in play. And yes, their effects are being felt and will be felt with greater force in the future.
But Mr. Friedman fails to mention the starting point. Rather blandly he notes that countries with borders that are "mostly straight lines" without any correspondence to "ethnic, tribal or religious realities" are the ones that are disintegrating. As a bland statement of current reality he is right. But as I said earlier, he fails to mention that it was these very colonial powers that, in their hunger and lust to control this region's natural resources, intentionally drew these rather arbitrary boundaries. And the unintended consequence is what we are witnessing today.

So, even as he notes the chaos permeating through this region, at the very least he needs to mention the role of colonists. Otherwise he is incomplete in his analysis.

asset.taxonomy: opinion/Whose Neighborhood Is It? (09edsall)
asset.assetTitle: Whose Neighborhood Is It? (09edsall)

newswire.title: Whose Neighborhood Is It?
newswire.abstract: The politics of integration and disintegration.

comments.commentBody:
"Schelling’s most striking finding is that moderate preferences for same-color neighbors at the individual level can be amplified into complete residential segregation at the macro level."

Basically what this means is that even if individuals or individual firms engage in a behavior that has minor negative consequences, it gets amplified at the macro level leading to huge problems.

Take the case of the recent financial meltdown from the recent past. Typically the FED works to preserve the health of the financial system and not of individual financial businesses. In fact many FED officers have publicly stated that they will allow individual institutions to fail in order to preserve the health of the financial sector. However, as we saw, a few banks "misbehaving" led to more banks "misbehavior" which in turn led to the systemic collapse of the financial sector.

What does this all mean? In complex systems, we often assume that individual actions do not have much of an effect on the entire system. This may be true in some cases and to some degree only. But, just as often, small perturbations lead to unintended and unimagined consequences. We need to be cognizant of this effect and vigilantly guard against it.

multimedia.caption: Doug Glanville

newswire.abstract: Inevitably, there will be a day when our favorite players have to walk away from the game — or, bad enough, from the team we love.

comments.commentBody:
You show a great knowledge of human psychology when you note as to how a teen, 20, 30, 40 year old, or even older folks will react to a trade or retirement of their favorite player.
And you show a great mastery of the language and writing in the way you have phrased this idea.
A simple yet great idea that sings when written thus:

"The teens are horrified, the 20-somethings are in denial and rant about the conspiracy of business, the 30-somethings realize that their childhood has just ended, the 40-somethings see it as a microcosm of life, and those who are considerably older than the people involved marvel at how these players are not rookies any more."

Bea-oo-tiful, simply mah-velous!!

Well said, Mr. Egan! St. Reagan was a practical man in most respects. ha raised taxes and the debt ceiling when required. He was for sensible gun control laws.

But in case of advancing American interests globally he was reckless. He got away scotfree in the Iran-Contra affair. And in order to blunt the Soviets in Afghanistan, he armed the mujaheddin that morphed into the Taliban. Just ask anyone in India about the mess that still prevails in that region. Or go read the book or see the movie "Charlie's War."

asset.taxonomy: opinion/The New Romantics in the Computer Age (04brooks)
asset.assetTitle: The New Romantics in the Computer Age (04brooks)

taxonomies.name: The New Romantics in the Computer Age (04brooks)

newswire.title: The New Romantics in the Computer Age
newswire.abstract: The tasks where humans will continue to stand out above technology are mostly soft and squishy relational stuff.

comments.commentBody:
In today's advice column David is foretelling me (sitting on the proverbial couch) that the nature of jobs in the brave new world is changing and it is no longer sufficient to have a vocational skill. And that is because the relationships are far more important than transactions. Here are a few snippets:

1. Those tasks are mostly relational.
2. Being a caregiver.
3. Being part of a team.
4. Empathy becomes a more important workplace skill, the ability to sense what another human being is feeling or thinking.

I get it. No more "Here is your burger, do you want fries with it" transactions. Instead it'll be "How are you feeling today? How can we co-create a burger that will befit your mood" orientation.

Apparently this emphasis on relationships is important only as we wade into the future. In the past it was "You can't afford to pay this high a mortgage, but please sign these papers and I'll loan you some money" transaction. If you signed it, it was your problem because they were not trying to build a relationship with you; they were only transacting with you for your money, and then body and soul. Which, of course, you did not know you were committing to.

It is interesting to read David's gushing love for the future built on relationships that will blossom out of the ashes of past transactions.

asset.taxonomy: opinion/Payday for Ice Bucket Challenge’s Mocked Slacktivists (03kristof)
asset.assetTitle: Payday for Ice Bucket Challenge’s Mocked Slacktivists (03kristof)

taxonomies.name: Payday for Ice Bucket Challenge’s Mocked Slacktivists (03kristof)

newswire.title: Payday for Ice Bucket Challenge’s Mocked Slacktivists
newswire.abstract: The fund-raising campaign that went viral last year contributed to what scientists say is a breakthrough in A.L.S. research.

comments.commentBody:
Kristof writes, "So think of armchair activism as a gateway drug. It exposes people to causes and sometimes gets them hooked."
In human psychology this is known as "foot-in-the-door" effect. Basically if a person makes a small pledge (the proverbial foot-in-the-door), then they have started to engage in a behavior that can become more regular (or, as Kristof puts it "gets them hooked").
Of course not everyone "gets hooked," but unless small steps are taken there will be no one to take the big steps.
Thanks for pointing that out. May there be more grass roots efforts that are fun to do and promote cures.

newswire.abstract: Now that the deal is done, it’s time to get tough on Iran.

comments.commentBody:
According to Mr. Burns the primary weakness of the Iran deal is that " it could permit Iran to emerge stronger 10 to 15 years from now as restrictions on its nuclear program begin to lapse."
While this is entirely possible, we know that Israel is currently a nuclear stae with over 200 nuclear warheads in her arsenal. What does the world want to do with that? Israel is not a signatory to the NPT and has quietly amassed her nuclear arsenal. And, in the process Israel also sold some of American secters to the Russians.
So, while it is fair to ask about Iran's status 15 years from now it is just as important to ask about Israel's nuclear program as of NOW.

taxonomies.name: Crash-Test Dummies as Republican Candidates for President (28krugman)

newswire.title: Crash-Test Dummies as Republican Candidates for President
newswire.abstract: The contenders are clueless in their China-bashing and bluster over volatile markets.

comments.commentBody:
Most of the people who run for POTUS will probably not be economic experts. But the sensible among them will reach out to experts and form a team that can advise them. Ditto in foreign policy, energy policy etc. Thus, it is the team advising a candidate that informs me about the candidate. Donald Trump needs no advise because he is all knowing. And Jeb Bush has his brother and other neocons on his foreign policy team. Marco Rubio's advisor, nay, patron saint, is Norman Bramann a car dealer whose economic or foreign policy credentials are wafer thin. And most others in the cavalcade aren't in any better position.
If you don't know something, ask an expert, but be careful who you call the expert. Also be prepared to read, listen and learn. But the Republican cavalcade is not only uninformed but also incurious.
As the old Persian adage attributed to Omar Khayyam notes, "He who knows not and knows not he knows not is a fool, shun him."

asset.taxonomy: opinion/Enough Is Enough (27blow)
asset.assetTitle: Enough Is Enough (27blow)

newswire.title: Enough Is Enough
newswire.abstract: When people refer to the press as the fourth estate, it shouldn’t be confused with a Trump property.

comments.commentBody:
Fox News was there doing its crazy thing for quite some time. And then along came John McCain who pickedpicked Sarah Palin as his running mate. Fox News was well positioned to add fuel to those flames. Obama's victory did not quell those flames. Mitch McConnell continued to fan those flames with his "make-Obama-a-one-term-President" idea. Fox News expanded its slate that now included the one and only Sarah Palin herself. Others like Sean Hannity and Mike Huckabee also personally benefited while adding to the craziness.

And now we have Donald Trump. He is the icing on top of this right wingnut cake that has been baking for almost one decade. He does not deserve a single minute's attention except he is getting all the attention. And the idea of not giving him the attention he so craves for is a great one. Except that he will continue to get more and more of it until he burns himself down.

So, let me be bold and make a prediction. Donald trump will continue to garner more and more attention and media coverage in the foreseeable short term. But he and his flames will be doused out soon thereafter. I can't say when but if I were to guess, I'd say in the next 6-8 months. Stay tuned!!

comments.commentBody:
All these men (and they are mostly men) will strongly support the right of the yet-to-be-born fetus since, in their world, it is a live human being. However, these very same men will not support policies that will provide food, education and healthcare for kids that are born. For some weird and warped reason, once born, kids become the sole responsibility of the parents and no help can be rendered by the state.
A fetus needs more support than a suffering child. You go figure that out!

multimedia.caption: An investor monitored stock data Monday at a securities brokerage house in Beijing.
An investor monitored stock data Monday at a securities brokerage house in Beijing.
An investor monitored stock data Monday at a securities brokerage house in Beijing.
An investor monitored stock data Monday at a securities brokerage house in Beijing.

newswire.abstract: World leaders need to come up with credible policies quickly to energize the sputtering global economy.

comments.commentBody:
Many years ago Paul Samuelson noted that "“The stock market has called nine of the last five recessions.”
There is no perfect way to predict markets. What goes up must come down. The idea of eternal growth is a chimera just as belief in eternal youth is.
This does not mean that nothing can be done. Of course there are policies that will stanch today's problems, but these too will be ephemeral.
We have to reprogram ourselves to realize that there are physical, chemical, and biological limits to all that we can do on planet earth.

newswire.abstract: The United States should help turn over Omar Hassan al-Bashir to the International Criminal Court.

comments.commentBody:
Yes, there is no warrant issued by the ICC on these men. But many activist judges in other countries can issue warrants. Case in point: Augusto Pinochet.

You can read that entire story here:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indictment_and_arrest_of_Augusto_Pinochet

Here is the gist in case you do not want to read the entire story:
General Augusto Pinochet was indicted for human rights violations committed in his native Chile by Spanish magistrate Baltasar Garzón on 10 October 1998. He was arrested in London six days later and held for a year and a half before finally being released by the British government in March 2000.

comments.commentBody:
Most of our wars in the recent past have ended in a stalemate and never been followed with an investment in the war-torn region. Examples: Vietnam, Afghanistan, Pakistan, Iraq. On the other hand look at how the Marshall Plan helped revitalize a war-torn Europe.
Helping Iranians get back on their feet and inviting them into the world order will go a long way in reducing tensions in that region.

asset.taxonomy: opinion/Debt Is Good (21krugman)
asset.assetTitle: Debt Is Good (21krugman)

newswire.title: Debt Is Good
newswire.abstract: A problem with the economy may be that we aren’t in deep enough, not that we’re in too deep.

comments.commentBody:
There is a big difference, a very big difference, between "spending" and "investing." Both require immediate expenditures, but one will dissipate soon whereas the other will payback many times over.
This is true even at an individual level. Suppose I take a loan of $100,000 and "spent" it on a big yacht and took it out on a Caribbean jaunt. At the end of that I will have the yacht and many dollars less than $100,000.
Suppose, instead, I took that money and "spent" it on an education or a business venture. At the end I will have a skill and a career that will payback many times more than $100,000.
Austerians do not seem to understand and appreciate this difference. Wheres they will cavalierly "spend" on invading Iran, they are loathe to "spending" on building our crumbling roads and bridges.

asset.taxonomy: opinion/How Not to Think About Bears (20druckerman)
asset.assetTitle: How Not to Think About Bears (20druckerman)

taxonomies.name: How Not to Think About Bears (20druckerman)

newswire.title: How Not to Think About Bears
newswire.abstract: I was making my family crazy with my obsession, crossing the line from heroic to panicky.

comments.commentBody:
Bears can be aggressive and pose a threat to humans. So can "sunburn, sugary cereals, and college rejections."
All of these and other unstated fears generally leads to not just a "catastrophic narrative in American parenting" but to a culture that is based on fear mongering and its appeasement.
I am old enough to remember the 1966 movie "The Russians are coming, the Russians are coming." It is a classic example of this phenomenon. A few Russians come ashore after their submarine runs aground and the entire community goes nuts in trying to combat this enemy.
It is prudent to be safe, but it is also smart to be judicious in our estimate of the danger.

newswire.title: Jeb Bush’s Slog: The Tortoise and the Hair
newswire.abstract: He’d better hurry up if he wants to finish ahead of Donald Trump and a raucous Republican field.

comments.commentBody:
Bruni notes of Bush, "He’s the most durable candidate."

Whether Bush is the most durable or not, his legacy and statements are most durable. Here is a short list:
1. He made the Terry Schaivo case into a political drama.
2. He got his bro' GWB elected President by invalidating votes and in spite of the fact that Gore had more votes.
3. He sat atop a Florida economic boom that was built on a housing bubble which went bust.
4. He refers to GWB as his reliable adviser on Middle East affairs.
5. He has Paul Wolfowitz on his foreign policy advisory team.

Any one of these in of itself should be enough to snuff out any Presidential aspirations, but collectively they are an avalanche of snow. The party elders may crave for him but I suspect thinking people will not.

comments.commentBody:
"What makes our country great is not that we are perfect, but that with time, courage and effort, we can become more perfect. What makes America special is our capacity to change."

This is the essence of the American ethos. We are not perfect, but we shall strive to attain perfection. Sadly, this runs counter to some people who would rather tout American exceptionalism. In their view, we have achieved perfection, although nothing can be farther from the truth than that smug belief. America's true exceptionalism lies in the fact that we continue to strive to be more perfect.

comments.commentBody:
The Donald's foray is "not an accident" and is aptly summed by "Talking nonsense is what you have to do to get anywhere in today’s Republican Party."

What started as a downward dip has become a deep dive down the never ending rabbit hole. The main question now has become who will talk "more" or "less" nonsense, for talking nonsense is a given and has become the default standard.

The memo to Rubio is just as applicable to anyone else. Please stop trying to defend yourself with the standard refrain, "I am not an expert on . . . " and start talking to actual experts who can inform you so you can set the correct direction and policies. Ultimately it is important to remember that the buck does stop with you.

comments.commentBody:
"The point is, there is really no reason the Clean Power Plan won’t work — except for political intransigence, which is far worse today than it was during the first Bush administration."

This hits the proverbial nail on its head. Political intransigence is what has been the watchword of every single GOP member for the past 7+ years. If Obama said that the sun rises in the east, of course that must be false because the sun rises in the west. If Obama said that Canada was our northern neighbor, well that cannot be true because our northern neighbor is Mexico.

Many people bear responsibility for this mess. John McCain, the straight talking express, kicked off the process by selecting Sarah-shoot-before-you-ask-Palin. Mitch McConnell continued this gambit with his call to make Obama a one-term President. And then the birthers, fueled by none other than the talk-through-your-a**-Donald, joined the caravan. There are many others but the list is too long to be fitted in this space.

The party that helped fight the acid rain problem will now pour acid over anything just to show you how bad Obama is.

asset.taxonomy: opinion/The Donald’s Gifts for Jeb Bush (02douthat)
asset.assetTitle: The Donald’s Gifts for Jeb Bush (02douthat)

taxonomies.name: The Donald’s Gifts for Jeb Bush (02douthat)

newswire.title: The Donald’s Gifts for Jeb Bush
newswire.abstract: The former governor may be the biggest beneficiary of Trump’s splash into the Republican presidential candidate pool.

comments.commentBody:
It was always clear that the Donald would make other Republican contenders look more normal. That much I agree. But that does not make them any less dangerous or more appealing. Douthat goes on to note that this would allow JEB to run his campaign "without having controversy dogging his every centrist foray." And this is a bald-faced brazen misrepresentation for at least two reasons.

First of all, there is nothing centrist about JEB, the man who helped steal the election for his brother. You may also recall his shenanigans in case of Terry Schiavo. I wonder what can be less centrist than those.

Second, he "forays" into centrist territory from time to time only to retreat back to his hardened evangelical right wing orientation. A foray is a sudden raid into enemy territory to take something before retreating into safe harbor. So beware of the JEB who will "foray" but never give up his safe harbor among the right wing ideologues.

asset.taxonomy: opinion/Revenge of the Ideologues: Killing the Export-Import Bank (01nocera)
asset.assetTitle: Revenge of the Ideologues: Killing the Export-Import Bank (01nocera)

taxonomies.name: Revenge of the Ideologues: Killing the Export-Import Bank (01nocera)

newswire.title: Revenge of the Ideologues: Killing the Export-Import Bank
newswire.abstract: The bank helps big and small American businesses compete globally while turning a profit for the Treasury.

comments.commentBody:
Nocera notes that "In truth, a vast majority of senators — Republicans included — very much want to see the Ex-Im Bank live to lend another day. So do most businesspeople, no matter what their politics."

Thus, it would seem that reauthorizing the Ex-Im Bank ought to be a no-brainer since it has broad support across both parties and many in the business community.

What then gives? As we know from so many other case, we need to only follow the money. Interestingly enough, just yesterday the NYT did a story on the Koch brothers in which the following was noted:
"But several hundred like-minded donors are members of Freedom Partners and more than two dozen donors have signed the op-ed articles, which take up familiar Koch causes like abolishing the Export-Import Bank or cutting the size of the federal government."

So, while it may be true that many of our Congress(wo)men and business people support reauthorizing Ex-Im Bank, the big money is on killing it. Need I say any more.

Here is the link to the article in the NYT from yesterday:
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/31/us/koch-brothers-brave-spotlight-to-tr...

newswire.title: We Invited Donald Trump to Town
newswire.abstract: The mouthy magnate is the carnival we summoned by letting our popular and political cultures bleed into one.

comments.commentBody: Democracy has built into it a popularity contest. After all the job goes to the man (or woman) who garners the most votes. But, once on the job, we expect that person to have the smarts, the savvy, the skills and the demeanor befitting that job even as display a lighter human side of themselves. There is nothing inherently wrong in a Bill Clinton playing his saxophone or GWB dancing in Africa (even if poorly). But there is everything wrong when the person does not know the difference between the professional and personal. And it is even worse when the media plays that up . And it is absolutely intolerable when we, the citizens, lap that up and egg them do be even more silly.

asset.taxonomy: opinion/Guns and the Two Americas (31egan)
asset.assetTitle: Guns and the Two Americas (31egan)

newswire.title: Guns and the Two Americas
newswire.abstract: One is safer. The other is an open-fire zone, backed by politicians who think it should be even more crowded with people parading around with lethal weapons.

comments.commentBody:
According to the right wingers who defend the indefensible sentence in the second amendment (more on that later) "everyone should be armed, everywhere." By their warped logic this will reduce the incidence of gun violence and gun deaths because "Once a shooting starts, the bad guy with the gun will be killed by the good guy with the gun." While reading this logic, I hope you did not fall off your chair laughing, crying or just exasperated. Do they not realize that "even if the bad guy with the gun will be killed" in the meantime there would have been many more good guys with a gun that would have been killed too. In other words, to catch one bad guy, we'll be sacrificing many good guys. Of course they know that, at least deep down. But they cannot say that publicly because that will not help gun sales. And that is the real reason why you see them inventing more and more ways, one weirder than the other, to defend the indefensible in the second amendment.

I have always had one suggestion for these right wing defenders of the second amendment. They are entitled to a gun, a manually loading musket. No more, no less. And they can also go on their horse and buggy to the village dealer to buy that musket and gunpowder.

newswire.title: China’s Naked Emperors
newswire.abstract: The politicians in Beijing who have ruled during economic booms, not unlike many of their American counterparts, have no idea what they’re doing.

comments.commentBody:
Market corrections are always hard and hit different people. But when it affects the wealthy and politically well-connected, it seems the government (I'm looking at you too America) will step in to stem the rot. This is another classic example of privatizing profits and socializing losses.
The lesson is that the Chinese have learnt this lesson very well. After all they had a great teacher.

asset.taxonomy: opinion/Why the Naysayers Are Wrong About the Iran Deal (30kristof)
asset.assetTitle: Why the Naysayers Are Wrong About the Iran Deal (30kristof)

taxonomies.name: Why the Naysayers Are Wrong About the Iran Deal (30kristof)

newswire.title: Why the Naysayers Are Wrong About the Iran Deal

related_urls.suggested_link_text: One Congressman’s Iran

newswire.abstract: Sure, the agreement is flawed, but it would make us safer.

comments.commentBody:
In the real world issues are resolved in a manner that requires both parties to compromise. As Kristof notes, "The U.S. didn’t get all it wanted (and neither did Iran) in an imperfect compromise."
And, of course, as expected, this has sent the right wingers into conniptions. Why can't Kerry wait and get a better deal, say some. What constitutes that "better deal" is never specified. Unless it is a complete lock down on Iranian capability. What is conveniently forgotten is that even as we press for a better deal, Iran will make progress. As has already been established by the fact that since GWB turned down an offer to negotiate in 2003, Iran has multiplied its centrifuges many-fold.
Another aspect that is conveniently overlooked is that in the P5+1 group, we are the least affected by sanctions on Iran. All others in that group have much more at stake and will withdraw from the sanctions regime, if not publicly, very discreetly. And that will leave America as the loser.
Lastly, there is no mention of the rather huge white elephant in the room. Israel, a non-signatory to the NPT regime, has nuclear weapons. Will Israel agree to keep their nukes under international supervision?
It is not a perfect deal, but it is a very good deal. Let us not make the perfect the enemy of the good.

newswire.title: Scavengers Are India’s Real Recyclers
newswire.abstract: If Modi really wants to create wealth out of waste, there is a workforce waiting for him.

comments.commentBody:
As this writer notes, " . . . it is Mr. Modi’s campaign that seems to have been binned. The prime minister is no longer seen sweeping, and absent his example, neither is anyone else."
This says it all. Do we need a Modi or anyone in high office to be seen sweeping so all people will follow? Or isn't it self evident that there is a need to sweep and keep one's neighborhoods clean?
Leaders can set the tone but it is beyond silly to expect them to do the obvious.

asset.assetTitle: ‘Wage Justice Is on the Menu’ (28bittman-california-matters)

newswire.title: ‘Wage Justice Is on the Menu’
newswire.abstract: In just a few years, the issue of labor in the food industry has gone from being largely ignored to drawing the attention of the entire country.

comments.commentBody: I have always had a jaundiced view on tipping not because I grudge a higher wage for the food worker but because it has really become a regular part of the price of food. Whenever I see an item on the menu that is marked at $12.99, I know it is really that plus the 15-20% gratuity which makes the price about $15-16.  Why not pay them a fair wage and list the price at $16? That way tipping will go back to what it was originally intended for - giving an additional amount OUT of FREE WILL to recognize EXCEPTIONAL SERVICE.

asset.taxonomy: opinion/For the Mideast, It’s Still 1979 (29friedman)
asset.assetTitle: For the Mideast, It’s Still 1979 (29friedman)

newswire.title: For the Mideast, It’s Still 1979
newswire.abstract: Events 36 years ago still shape the region, but that could change.

comments.commentBody:
Tom Friedman notes "That competition was further fueled by the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan in 1979 — which spawned the Sunni jihadist movement and eventually Al Qaeda."
Whoa, Tom, you better stop there and take another look at your statement. The Soviet invasion of Afghanistan was countered by the proxy war funded by the USA via the mujaheddin. BTW, this was on St. Reagan's watch. As soon as the Soviets pulled out of Afghanistan, the US of A stopped their support in war torn Afghanistan. Had the arming of the mujaheddin been followed by aid to build infrastructure (roads, bridges and such that were destroyed in the war) and schools, there might have been no Al Qaeda.
There is no a straight line from the Soviet invasion to the creation of Al Qaeda; it was aided and abetted by the USA. Without that major assist there may have been no Al Qaeda. So blame the Russians, but do not overlook America's role.

asset.taxonomy: opinion/Today’s Exhausted Superkids (29bruni)
asset.assetTitle: Today’s Exhausted Superkids (29bruni)

newswire.title: Today’s Exhausted Superkids
newswire.abstract: Overpacked days lead to restless nights, and more experts are rightly questioning the sense — and safety — of that.

comments.commentBody:
Sleep deprivation is a problem particularly among the "ambitious, privileged subset of Americans" as Bruni notes.
But then why is this a problem worthy of our attention and a column in the NYT? After all it afflicts a small subset. There is a larger. much larger, group of students who do not have access to college thanks to the shrinking support by states to State U. There is another large group that is drowning in college loan debts that our predatory banks will not write off even as our Congress will not pass a bill making it easier for college bound students to get a loan.
So while I sympathize with the "insanely programmed, status-obsessed and sometimes spirit-sapping race" being played out in the "insanely programmed, status-obsessed and sometimes spirit-sapping race" being played out in the "ambitious, privileged subset of Americans," I will not lose much sleep over that problem.
OTOH waking our Congress and states from their slumber is a cause worthy of losing sleep.

asset.assetTitle: Stepping on a Slippery Slope (28nocera)

newswire.title: Stepping on a Slippery Slope
newswire.abstract: A podcast’s lines between journalism and advertising.

comments.commentBody: There is always an uneasy alliance and partnership between advertising and journalism.  And in a hyperconnected world these distinctions between different institutions and people becomes more and more difficult to discern. Nocera's warning about the slippery slope is well intended and worth taking note of. But ultimately we live in an interconnected world. And it becomes incumbent on each one of us to ensure that we do not cross that line even as we navigate our way in this complex world of institutions and people.

asset.taxonomy: opinion/The Structure of Gratitude (28brooks)
asset.assetTitle: The Structure of Gratitude (28brooks)

newswire.title: The Structure of Gratitude
newswire.abstract: In some sense, being thankful is a result of life exceeding our expectations.

comments.commentBody:
Two sentences jumped out of this column and made me wonder if David has left his GOP camp and joined the Elizabeth Warren camp. Here below are those two sentences:

"But people with dispositional gratitude are hyperaware of their continual dependence on others."
"They’re glad the ideal of individual autonomy is an illusion because if they were relying on themselves they’d be much worse off."

Isn't this just another way of saying what President Obama did sometime back when he said "You didn't build that."
Or what Elizabeth Warrens said addressing the drug companies " . . . . didn't do it alone."

At that time David's many GOP friends lambasted the President and candidate Warren. And David kept quiet. Was he just biding time so he could adapt and adopt that idea for this column today?

asset.taxonomy: opinion/The Minimum-Wage Muddle (24brooks)
asset.assetTitle: The Minimum-Wage Muddle (24brooks)

newswire.title: The Minimum-Wage Muddle
newswire.abstract: Mandates for better pay will certainly help some people, but hurt some, too.

comments.commentBody:
"Some of my Democratic friends are arguing that forcing businesses to raise their minimum wage will not only help low-wage workers; it will actually boost profits, because companies will better retain workers. Some economists have reported that there is no longer any evidence that raising wages will cost jobs.
Unfortunately, that last claim is inaccurate."

Notice how Mr. Brooks notes two findings but gets away refuting only one. Likewise he does not acknowledge that there are studies which show that companies may end up showing a marginal reduction in profits when the minimum wage is raised. He also does not touch upon the fact that CEOs of these companies make obscene salaries in comparison to their lowest paid employees. Why not follow the example of Dan Price of Gravity Payments in Seattle who cut his own salary by a whopping $930,000 so that the lowest paid employee made $70,000 a year.
In other words there are many ways by which one can support a higher minimum wage. And unless one is a heartless brute, raising the minimum wage to $15 should be a no-brainer.
On a lighter note, I see that Mr. Brooks has expanded his group of friends that includes Democrats! Bravo!!

So, I agree with you. We have been fleeced. It is time to give peace a chance.

newswire.abstract: How Kenya fits into Barack Obama’s identity remains one of the enduring questions of his presidency.

comments.commentBody:
"Mr. Obama considered the “birther” movement, now largely defunct, a distraction and a cynical ploy by opponents like Donald J. Trump, but he stayed away from Kenya until now, unwilling to provoke the obvious political circus that would have ensued. "
Isn't it sad that Obama was badgered by the birthers to show them he was an American citizen but none of them was forced to show they had a functioning brain?
And isn't it irony that the Donald is back in action as the leading Republican in the clown car?
I, for one, extend you Mr. President the very best on your trip. May you have a safe trip.

asset.taxonomy: opinion/To Trump or Not to Trump? (22bruni)
asset.assetTitle: To Trump or Not to Trump? (22bruni)

taxonomies.name: To Trump or Not to Trump? (22bruni)

newswire.title: To Trump or Not to Trump?
newswire.abstract: As Donald Trump becomes bigger, we become smaller. How should we size him up?

comments.commentBody:
As Bruni correctly notes, discussing Trump reward his bad behavior while ignoring it might be construed as being irresponsible. This is perfect case of damned if you do and damned if you don't.
But that looks at this issue from the media's perspective. What if we looked at it from the averagee. American citizen's perspective. We, the viewers and readers, are enthralled by these freak shows and so the media feeds it to us. If only we decided to be less voyeuristic and more analytical, the media will drop Trump faster than a hot potato.
So let us look at ourselves in the mirror and recognize that we are getting what we asked for and deserve. Nothing more, nothing less.

asset.taxonomy: opinion/Dustin Yellin’s Modern Community-Building (21brooks)
asset.assetTitle: Dustin Yellin’s Modern Community-Building (21brooks)

newswire.title: Dustin Yellin’s Modern Community-Building
org_facet: Pioneer Works Center for Art and Innovation (Brooklyn, NY)
newswire.abstract: A New York artist draws together artists, physicists and others into a uniquely modern collective of creativity.

comments.commentBody:
I am always impressed (and intrigued) by people such as Yellin whose path is uncommon. But I am also wary of holding such people as role models for others to follow. For most of us the traditional path is the most likely path to a "good life."
When people point to Steve Jobs and say "Look he's a college dropout who learnt calligraphy and went on to build the Apple empire" I cringe because that is not a path for anyone other than Steve Jobs. Same thing in regards your soulmate and colleague at NYT, Arthur Brooks, who often writes about how he wandered around and then found his calling.
For most of us our calling is in doing the normal boring things but finding ways to make them interesting. I am just as impressed by a high school teacher who takes the extra time to help out a child with disability who can build upon that to construct a more "normal life for him/herself. I am in awe of a veteran who comes back and helps out fellow veterans who are suffering from PTSD.
Geniuses stand out for that very reason and deserve all our appreciation but it is the everyday little acts of generosity that makes the world a tad bit better.

newswire.abstract: Donald Trump has become the new starring attraction for the restless, conservative-minded voters who think the political process is in need of disruption.

comments.commentBody:
"The praise they heap on Mr. Trump — “He speaks the truth,” “He’s fearless,” “He’s not politically correct” — echoes the words conservatives have used to describe others, like Sarah Palin and Senator Ted Cruz of Texas, who have stirred their passions before."

He speaks the truth - No he does not.
He's fearless - No he is afraid of losing, his money, his hair, this election.
He's not politically correct - Yes, you can say that gain.

What he is successfully doing is making the rest of the Republican field look normal. And that is the scariest part of his being in the race. Besides the fact that he naturally provides much material for our laughter.
